p.s: Every quatrain and the final couplet have their own intention and meaning for the sonnet.
The first quatrain in there to present the subject of the sonnet.
It raises a question which is then answered in the final couplet.
So the couplet contains the core of the sonnet.
The second quatrain brings further imagery and metaphor to the question being raised in The first quatrain.
This imagery is then followed by a twist in the last quatrain.
That twist extends the imagery given beforhandbeforehand and adds meaning to the main theme or subject.
The strong imagery in the second quatrain is supported by ShakespearShakespeare deliverigdelivering a hard contrast to the reader.
He mentions summer's honey breath (l. 5) and personificates it to show how delightful nature can be.
Then he immediately creates the image of it being destroyed and compares it to rocks and steel.
This contrast is there to show how much humans impact the spoil of beauty (l. 12) in nature.
Even this personification spoil of beauty just further exageratesexaggerates this image of it being slowly but steady destroyed.
The first verse an immediate image of the dimension and which humanhumans are abuotabout to destroy nature.
By using this alliteration with nor and using more and more bigger areas of nature he shows that there are no boundriesboundaries given to the extendextent of destruction.
The question Whose action is no stronger than a flower? is intentionally absurd and implicates from the beginning that nature isn't safe from anybody.
All those comparisons and personifications lead to the reader being more and more shocked or even inspired by his message.

All in all Shakespeare's intention is to either give attention to the topic of naturesnature's destroy caused by human or to just show how well sonnets and poetry can show and embodieembody the beauty of nature.
With that being his intention Sonnet 65 can be put in the context of sonnets which ShakespearShakespeare adressedaddressed to his beloved friend.
